title: Noles News : Four reasons why FSU & Clemson  won  the settlement
body_text:
Florida State football, recruiting news: Four reasons why FSU & Clemson “won” the settlement
The agreement would create six years of stability for the ACC
Massive news released yesterday of a report in which FSU, Clemson, and the ACC are set to agree on a settlement that will keep FSU and Clemson in the conference until 2030 under a new payout model.
More detailed analysis is soon to follow once the full details are released and voted on but in my opinion this settlement is a major victory for FSU and Clemson because it accomplishes four things:
- A payout of up to $15 million annually before performance-based incentives kick in
- It lowers the reported cost of leaving the ACC from over $700 million to less than $100 million
- Makes it so FSU and Clemson can exit the ACC for that significantly lowered price in 2030 right when major TV deals are set to renew (Big Ten, B12, and the College Football Playoff)
- It immediately stops the bleeding that is legal fees b/c the lawyers on both side were making a killing.
Micahi Danzy earned 3rd place at his first ACC Championship Meet:
He’ll be moving from RB to WR this spring.
Despite all the new faces at the skill positions and on the sidelines; the position of intrigue this spring is the offensive line.
Position of intrigue: Take your pick. At virtually every spot, Florida State has a big question after last year’s debacle. QB certainly fits the bill as “intriguing,” but BC transfer Thomas Castellanos isn’t likely to change a lot of hearts and minds this spring by himself. The bigger issue might be getting the O-line in order after an unmitigated disaster last season. If FSU can’t block, it won’t matter who’s in the backfield.
